Location: On No. Side Co. Rd. 49 Near W. End Bridge Over Minisink R.
Marker text: Built 1873 By Westfall & Cuddeback. Sawed Lumber To Rebuild Houses Burned By Brant In Minisink (Port Jervis) 1778-79

Location: On NYS 97 About 1½ Mis. E. of Minisink Ford.
Marker text: Col. Joseph Brant Led 40 Mohawks And Tories Up This Ravine And Ambushed N.Y. And N.J. Militia Lying For Him On Hill To The West
Entrance To Battlefield Where July 22, 1779, N.Y. And N.J. Militia Attacked Mohawk And Tory Raiders of Minisink (Port Jervis)

Location: On NYS 97 About 1 Mi. West of Entrance To Battlefield.
Marker text: One of The Deadliest In Frontier Warfare, Between Militia And Brant's Tories And Mohawks, On This Hill July 22, 1779

Location: On NYS 97 About 1/2 Mile East of Entrance To Battlefield.
Marker text: On This Hill, July 22, 1779 N.Y. And N.J. Militia Were Decimated By Mohawk And Tory Raiders of Minisink, (Port Jervis) Under Brant
The Mohawk Leader of Raid On Minisink (Port Jervis) Camped Here July 21, 1779. Pursuing Militia Camped 3 Miles Up This Same Brook

Location: On NYS 97 Near Entrance To Battlefield
Marker text: After Battle of Minisink Brants Raiders With Their Plunder Forded River Here To Camp At Mouth of The Lackawaxen Creek Opposite
Built By John A. Roebling, Builder of Brooklyn Bridge, To Support D. & H. Canal Aqueduct By Which Boats Crossed Delaware, 1848–98

Location: On NYS 52 About 1 Mile East of White Sulphur Springs
Marker text: Joseph And Ebenezer Hill Came From Conn., 1807 Bought 5000 Acres In Hardenbergh Patent. Joseph Was Captain In War of 1812.
In Robertsonville Now Called White Sulphur Springs 1812
